summary: This document is the curriculum vitae of Dr. Gail S. Goodman, a Distinguished Professor of Psychology at UC Davis, specializing in child witness testimony, memory, and the effects of abuse and legal involvement on children. It details her extensive education, professional experience, research grants, and awards, establishing her as a leading expert in forensic child psychology. The document is part of the Epstein case files, likely submitted to establish her credentials as an expert witness. This document is a detailed curriculum vitae or professional biography for Dr. Gail S. Goodman, listing her extensive academic appointments, professional memberships, committee work, and publications. It establishes her as a leading expert in child development, child witness testimony, and child abuse research, with a career spanning decades and involvement with numerous national and international organizations. This document is a bibliography listing academic publications by Gail S. Goodman and her co-authors, primarily focusing on child witness research, memory development, and child sexual abuse investigations. It appears to be part of a legal filing, possibly an expert witness disclosure or background material, as it is marked 'SUBJECT TO PROTECTIVE ORDER'. This document appears to be a bibliography or list of publications by Dr. Gail S. Goodman and her co-authors, submitted as part of a court filing. It focuses on research related to child witness memory, suggestibility, trauma, and forensic interviewing, likely to establish expert credentials in a case involving child testimony. This document appears to be an appendix or exhibit, likely part of a legal filing, listing the extensive publication and presentation history of Dr. Gail S. Goodman, a prominent research psychologist specializing in child witness testimony, memory, and child maltreatment. The list includes academic publications, amicus briefs, and conference presentations spanning decades, suggesting it was submitted to establish her expertise. This document appears to be an exhibit, likely part of a court filing, listing numerous academic publications and conference presentations by Dr. Gail S. Goodman and her collaborators from 1992 to 2004. The publications focus on research into children's eyewitness testimony, memory for traumatic/stressful events, suggestibility, false memory, and the legal system's handling of child abuse cases. Its significance lies in establishing the expert credentials and research background of Dr. Goodman, who was likely an expert witness in a case related to child abuse or testimony. This document appears to be a curriculum vitae or professional biography for Dr. Gail S. Goodman, detailing her extensive career as a research psychologist specializing in child witnesses, memory, trauma, and child maltreatment. It lists numerous invited addresses, presentations, and professional activities from 1993 to 2022, establishing her as a leading expert in the field relevant to child abuse cases.

persons.name: Gail S. Goodman
persons.role: Distinguished Professor of Psychology, Expert Witness
persons.context: The subject of the CV, a prominent researcher specializing in child witnesses, memory of traumatic events, and child maltreatment. She has given hundreds of invited addresses worldwide and testified as an expert in courts.

persons.name: Bette L. Bottoms
persons.context: Recipient of a predoctoral fellowship sponsored by Gail S. Goodman for research on attitudes toward child victim/witnesses of sexual abuse (1991-1992).

persons.name: Jodi A. Quas
persons.context: Recipient of multiple fellowships and grants sponsored by Goodman, and later a Co-PI on a child maltreatment transitions grant. Research focused on self-blame in child victims and effects of repeated interviews.

persons.name: Jianjian Qin
persons.context: Recipient of a National Science Foundation dissertation grant sponsored by Goodman for research on true vs. false memories of childhood (1997-1999).

persons.name: Simona Ghetti
persons.context: Recipient of a dissertation grant sponsored by Goodman and later a Co-PI on a false memory resistance grant. Research focused on children's heuristics and false events.

persons.name: Ingrid Cordon
persons.context: Recipient of a National Science Foundation dissertation grant sponsored by Goodman for research on influencing children's eyewitness memory (2004-2005).

persons.name: LaTonya Harris
persons.context: Recipient of a National Science Foundation dissertation grant sponsored by Goodman for research on child maltreatment and eyewitness memory (2009-2010).

persons.name: Kelly McWilliams
persons.context: Recipient of a National Science Foundation dissertation grant sponsored by Goodman for research on parent-child discussion and eyewitness memory (2013-2015).

persons.name: Daniel Bederian-Gardner
persons.context: Recipient of a National Science Foundation dissertation grant sponsored by Goodman for research on children lying to conceal parental transgression (2014-2016).

persons.name: Jonni Johnson
persons.context: Recipient of a National Science Foundation dissertation grant sponsored by Goodman for research on eyewitness memory in children with autism spectrum disorder (2016-2017).

persons.name: Mitchell Eisen
persons.context: Principal Investigator on a grant where Gail S. Goodman was Co-Principal Investigator, studying the impact of dissociation and trauma on memory in abused children (1994-1998).

persons.name: D. Whitcomb
persons.context: Principal Investigator on a National Institute of Justice grant synthesizing findings on emotional effects of courtroom testimony on child victims, with Goodman as Co-Investigator (1991-1993).

persons.name: Michael J. Lawler
persons.context: Principal Investigator for the San Pasqual Academy evaluation at the University of South Dakota, with Goodman as PI for the UC Davis subcontract (2012-2013).

persons.name: Steven Clark
persons.context: Principal Investigator for the UC Consortium on Social Sciences and Law grant, with Goodman as Co-Principal Investigator (2014-2017).

persons.name: Cindy Miller-Perrin
persons.context: Principal Investigator on an APA survey on psychologists' views of spanking children, with Goodman listed as a Co-Investigator (2015-2016).

persons.name: D. Shestowsky
persons.context: Co-Principal Investigator with Goodman on a grant for an interdisciplinary/international collaboration in psychology and law (2019-2022).

persons.name: M. M. Haith
persons.context: Co-Investigator with Goodman on an early grant titled 'The Child Witness' (1981-1984).

persons.name: M. J. Farrar
persons.context: Co-Investigator with Goodman on a grant for research on children's memory for repeated events (1986-1987).

persons.name: K. Saywitz
persons.context: Named as the Principal Investigator (PI) for a literature review project on eliciting reliable reports from children, for which Goodman served on the advisory board.

persons.name: W. E. Jeffrey
persons.context: Chairperson of Gail S. Goodman's doctoral dissertation at UCLA in 1977.

persons.name: B. L. Bottoms
persons.context: Frequent co-author with Gail S. Goodman on research related to child testimony, religion-related child abuse, and international perspectives on children's testimony.

persons.name: J. A. Quas
persons.context: Frequent co-author with Gail S. Goodman on studies about trauma, memory, suggestibility, and child witnesses in forensic contexts.

persons.name: J. J. Qin
persons.context: Frequent collaborator and co-author with Gail S. Goodman on research concerning maltreated children's memory, suggestibility, and false memory.

persons.name: A. Tobey
persons.context: Co-author with Gail S. Goodman on early work regarding memory development in the context of child sexual abuse investigations and the effects of closed-circuit television on testimony.

persons.name: K. J. Saywitz
persons.context: Co-author with Gail S. Goodman on publications about interviewing children in and out of court and the psychological research on child witnesses.

persons.name: S. Ghetti
persons.context: Co-author with Gail S. Goodman on studies about memory distortion, false memories, eyewitness testimony, and the long-term outcomes for child sexual assault victims.

persons.context: Co-author with Gail S. Goodman on research concerning hearsay evidence, children's memory, and the effects of legal involvement on children.

persons.context: Co-author with Gail S. Goodman on research involving emotion and eyewitness memory, attachment style, and detecting deception in children and adults.

persons.name: J. E. B. Myers
persons.context: Co-author with Gail S. Goodman on handbooks for child witnesses and research on jurors' perceptions of hearsay in child sexual abuse cases.

persons.name: I. Cordon
persons.context: Co-author with Gail S. Goodman on publications about children in court, memory for traumatic events in early childhood, and interview techniques.

persons.name: D. P. H. Jones
persons.context: Co-author with Gail S. Goodman on studies predicting outcomes for sexually abused children and models of children's disclosure of sexual abuse.

persons.context: Co-author with Gail S. Goodman on research about individual differences in suggestibility and children's eyewitness memory.

persons.context: Co-author with Goodman on studies about memory, emotion, and child witnesses in court.

connections.description: Goodman served as Principal Investigator/Faculty Sponsor for Quas's predoctoral and dissertation fellowships, and later they were Co-PIs on a research grant.
Goodman sponsored Ghetti's dissertation grant and later served as Co-Principal Investigator with Ghetti on a major NSF grant.
Collaborated on a major grant from the National Center on Child Abuse and Neglect, with Eisen as PI and Goodman as Co-PI.
Collaborated on an NIJ grant synthesizing research on emotional effects of courtroom testimony on child victims.
Goodman served as an advisory board member/consultant for a research project led by Saywitz.
Jeffrey was the chairperson of Goodman's doctoral dissertation committee.
Frequent co-authors and editors on academic research and books concerning child testimony and abuse.
Extensive co-authorship on research about trauma, memory, and child witnesses in forensic settings.
Multiple co-authored studies on memory distortion, false memories, and eyewitness testimony in children.
Co-authors on research about children's eyewitness memory and repressed memories of abuse.
Co-authors on research concerning hearsay evidence and the legal involvement of children.
Co-authors on studies about child witnesses, attachment, and memory for stressful events.
Co-authors on research involving emotion, memory, and detecting deception.
Regular co-authors on studies concerning child memory, trauma, and testimony in forensic contexts.
Co-authors and co-editors of journal special issues focused on child victim witnesses and legal procedures.
Co-editors of a special journal issue on child witness research and co-authors on related studies.
Frequent co-authors on numerous academic papers focusing on child memory, trauma, and suggestibility, indicating a close and long-term research partnership.
Collaborators on research projects and symposiums concerning child witness credibility and the emotional effects of court involvement on children.
Co-authors on research and chapters concerning memory for child sexual abuse, indicating a collaborative research relationship.
Co-authors on multiple papers regarding child witnesses, at-risk youth, and self-representation in court.
Collaborators on amicus briefs and research; Goodman co-authored an obituary for Saywitz, indicating a significant professional and personal relationship.
Frequent co-authors and co-chairs of symposia on children's eyewitness memory, victimization, and legal experiences.
Co-authors on multiple studies and co-chairs of symposia focusing on maltreated children's memory, trauma, and suggestibility.
Lamb organized conferences where Goodman was an invited speaker and they co-chaired a symposium at the American Psychological Association in 2016.
Both were featured as 'Eminent Psychologists' in the same university colloquium series in 1994.
Goodman gave an award address named in honor of Karen J. Saywitz, indicating recognition within the same professional field.

events.title: APA Convention on Children's Eyewitness Testimony
events.description: Symposium presented in Washington, D.C., chaired by Bottoms & Levine, featuring work by Schwartz-Kenney et al. and Goodman.

events.title: DOJ Conference on Children's Evidence
events.description: Goodman et al. presented invited paper at U.S. Department of Justice Conference on Criminal Justice Research and Evaluation in Washington, D.C., on effects of live testimony vs. hearsay on jurors.

events.title: APS-LS Convention on Children in Legal Cases
events.description: Goodman, Quas, and Ghetti chaired a major symposium titled 'Children in legal cases: Experiences and consequences' in New Orleans, presenting multiple studies on long-term effects of legal involvement on abuse victims.

events.title: APA Address on Child Victims/Witnesses
events.description: Goodman gave an invited address titled 'Child victims, child witnesses' at the American Psychological Association in Toronto.

events.title: Eminent Psychologists Colloquium
events.description: Goodman gave an invited address as part of a university-wide 'Eminent Psychologists' colloquium series at the University of Kentucky, alongside Robert Sternberg, Richard Petti, and Gordon Bower.

events.title: Conference on Religious Child Maltreatment
events.description: Goodman, Bottoms, Shaver, Qin, Nysse-Carris, and Toulou-Shams presented an invited talk titled 'In the name of God: A profile of child maltreatment justified by religious beliefs and perpetrated by religious authorities' at the Conference on Family Violence.

events.title: APA Distinguished Contributions Award
events.description: Goodman received and gave the award address for the APA Distinguished Contributions to Research in the Public Interest (senior) award in Washington, D.C.

events.title: Honorary Doctorate in Oslo
events.description: Goodman received an honorary doctorate and gave the award address at the University of Oslo, Norway.

events.title: Karen J. Saywitz Legacy Award Address
events.description: Goodman gave the Karen J. Saywitz Legacy Award Address for the California American Professional Society on the Abuse of Children (CAPSAC) in Los Angeles.

keyFacts: Dr. Gail S. Goodman is a preeminent expert in child witness testimony, memory development, and the psychological effects of abuse and legal involvement on children, with a career spanning over 40 years.

Her research has been directly funded by major agencies relevant to the Epstein case, including the National Institute of Justice and the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, focusing on child sexual assault victims and courtroom testimony.

She has served as a consultant to the Special Assault Forensic Evaluation Center (formerly Multidisciplinary Interview Center) for Sacramento County Child Protective Services, indicating direct involvement in forensic child abuse evaluations.

Her CV lists her as a founding member of the American Professional Society on the Abuse of Children (APSAC) and a recipient of its Research Career Achievement Award, underscoring her central role in the field of child abuse research.

The document is explicitly marked 'SUBJECT TO PROTECTIVE ORDER,' indicating it was filed under seal or with restrictions in a legal proceeding, likely to establish her expert qualifications in a case involving child victims.
Dr. Gail S. Goodman is a highly credentialed expert in child development and child witness testimony, with a career beginning in the late 1970s.
She has held numerous editorial board positions for major psychology and law journals, including Child Abuse & Neglect, Law and Human Behavior, and Child Development.

Goodman has served on advisory boards and committees for key national organizations like the American Psychological Association, the National Institute of Mental Health, and the National Children's Advocacy Center.
Her research has been cited by the U.S. Supreme Court, and she has submitted amicus briefs to the Court on behalf of the American Psychological Association.
The document shows deep, long-term institutional involvement in the fields of child abuse research, forensic psychology, and legal policy concerning child witnesses.
The document is a comprehensive bibliography of academic work by Gail S. Goodman, a leading researcher in child witness psychology and memory.
The research focuses heavily on child sexual abuse investigations, the reliability of children's testimony, interview techniques, and the effects of legal proceedings on child witnesses.
Several publications were cited in significant legal contexts, including a U.S. Supreme Court case (Kennedy v. Louisiana, 2008) and amicus briefs for cases like Roper v. Simmons.
The bibliography shows collaboration with a large network of researchers over decades, indicating Goodman's central role in this field of study.

Goodman's research focuses extensively on child witness testimony, memory for traumatic events (especially child sexual abuse), suggestibility, and the impact of legal procedures on children.
Her work has been cited by the U.S. Supreme Court, as noted for an amicus brief in Craig v. Maryland (1990) and a conference paper on the emotional effects of court involvement on children (1989).

Dr. Gail S. Goodman is a preeminent research psychologist with decades of expertise specifically in child witnesses, memory for traumatic events, and child maltreatment.
Her CV demonstrates she has been a sought-after expert witness, having testified in State and Federal Courts and given reports/testimony to countries' Supreme Courts.
